Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Situation2: They set aside part of their routine to light a lamp and offer prayers at their home altar.
Story: I glanced at the overflowing laundry basket, the shirts and socks spilling over the edge, a silent reminder of the promise I made to my wife to help more around the house. She had an early meeting tomorrow, and our son needed his uniform clean for school. I knew the laundry couldn’t wait. But as I reached for the detergent, I caught sight of the clock—almost sunset. My heart skipped. This was the sacred time I set aside each day to light the lamp and offer prayers at our home altar, a practice my parents instilled in me since childhood. Missing it felt like neglecting a part of myself, a quiet betrayal of my faith. Yet, the thought of my wife’s tired face and my son’s disappointment tugged at me. I stood frozen, torn between the hum of the washing machine and the soft glow of the altar, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which to choose.
